title: Do you think “Nothing Is Impossible”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, i used to think, “Nothing is impossible” But after giving it a certain amount of thought, i proved myself wrong. I would say, in my opinion, ‘Anything is possible’ i.e. ‘Nothing is impossible’ over the course of time. Some things seem impossible because the life span of matter is lesser than the required time to achieve the required ‘thing’. For example If we consider the possibilities of something impossible to occur, like i can say “I saw humans fly without any machinery”, it is highly unlikely to happen now. But over the course of time, after many millenniums has passed, it will occur and so that particular sentence is not absolutely a lie, but a thing which can occur in course of time. Let us stick to that particular sentence for now. Consider a possibility where a single human has an infinite life span, which means he would eventually see evolution and can finally say “I saw Humans fly without any machinery”, and so proving that ‘nothing is impossible if the time is right’ Consider this past incident, during the invention of phone, many thought, “Why is this so big and heavy, i wish i can have a small and convenient phone, but it seems impossible!” So they said, “The sentence ‘nothing is impossible’ is a lie!” But some persons worked hard to develop what they thought was impossible and now, we got what they thought to be impossible, proving that nothing is impossible over the course of time. Conclusion If and only if, the life span of a particular person/ place/ matter tends to be infinity, everything is possible i.e nothing is impossible… Unless the life span is infinity, this sentence is a paradox, and this sentence must be replaced by “Nothing is impossible if it is logical” or “Everything is possible if you can keep your mind to it”

Like they say, with vision, determination, and discipline, nothing is impossible. Prove me wrong. Is there a single thing in this uncertain world of ours that is by definition, “impossible?” NO! Of course, many people misinterpret the meaning of the word “impossible.” If something cannot be done now, does that mean that it will never be done? No, of course not. For example, we humans used to think that flying was impossible, that it was the stuff that only happened in fairytales. But look at our world now! Airplanes! People probably also thought, at a certain point in time, that seacraft made of metal was impossible. Well, look at our harbors now! Metal ships everywhere! So what really is impossible? In my opinion, nothing is strictly impossible. If you can’t do it, that doesn’t mean that others won’t be able to. A fish would obviously think that climbing a tree was impossible, but little did the fish know that it was indeed possible. For the fish, it was impossible, but for a monkey, it was possible. In the same way, the monkey would think that it was impossible to live in water, but the fish demonstrated to him that it was indeed possible. Now, there are some things that are possible but not plausible, as I like to say. Have you ever wondered why humans haven’t built any flying cities? Many people would say that such things are impossible. But are they really? No! Flying cities are possible, just not plausible. If you build a gigantic metal platform and attach millions upon billions of engines and propellers to it and build a city on the platform, you have a flying city! It is indeed possible, but the cost of building such a mammoth would be extremely high. That is why we are still stuck to the ground. But if something is deemed impossible now, that may change in the future. In some cases, particular things that were possible in the past are now impossible. A good example of this is Greek fire. In conclusion, is anything truly impossible! No! The Earthly view of this is, “With vision, determination, and discipline, nothing is impossible.” The correct way to view this is, “With God, anything is possible.” Have a great day.

No. In fact, all kinds of things are impossible. You can’t go faster than light. You can’t compress normal matter into infinitely small spaces. You can’t eat just one Lay’s potato chip. This saying is somewhat annoying. I think it gives people false hope in times when a dose of realism would do them good. If you’re tone deaf, spending your life trying out for American Idol might not be the best use of your time. Trying to join the NBA when you’re a 40 year old 5′10″ science teacher with almost no athletic abilities is genuinely foolish. That’s not to say people shouldn’t take risks, or even that people shouldn’t have dreams or goals. But, realize that the more unlikely your goals are to actually happen, the more likely you are to fail at achieving them. That failure can be OK - sometimes it can be really great. But, it can also be pretty awful. So, I’d like to replace the dreamy, vapid, and incorrect “Nothing is impossible” with the concrete, albeit utilitarian, “Set realistic goals and then strive to meet them.” Yeah, it’s not poetic or inspirational. It’s also not as potentially damaging and horribly incorrect, either.

When I read this question at first I was going to say “Of course some things are impossible”… However, I could not come up with even one example! Of course there can be things that seem impossible… but even those may be possible at times. Some of the most ridiculous things, that we 100% believe to be impossible today, may very well be possible tomorrow. In the future we may be able to grow wings, shoot fireballs from our hands, or lasers out of our eyes. We may be able to travel faster than the speed of light, may be able to create a universe in a laboratory or may be able to travel back in time. And while not impossible, these things are highly unlikely to happen. It used to be thought that flying was impossible, that we could never ever reach the moon or that Mt. Everest would kill everyone and anyone who tried to climb it. Those used to be indisputable facts in earlier years. No one doubted the validity of the impossibility of these things, yet, today, we have done all of them and more. Someone ran a mile under 4 minutes, someone made a device that can travel without the use of horses, and we even have light without fire! There are so many things that we deem as impossible just to avoid having to work for it. If it is impossible then there is no use in you trying… right? But the truth is that nothing is impossible.   That being said, please do not fall into the idea that you will get to do everything in your lifetime. While it is not impossible for you to do any one of these things, and is not impossible for you to do them all, it is getting far more unlikely the more you put on your plate. But there is always a chance. Relying on that chance is not always the best idea though. “Nothing is impossible” is not synonymous with “You can do Anything and Everything”. Make sure you ask yourself whether or not it’s worth it before you commit to the making the impossible possible.

Well, I’d say that this statement is both True and False in itself. I’ll explain both the scenarios. How this statement is TRUE? Let me explain this by taking one example from various times of the world. Example 1: Just suppose, if you were living in the year 1850 and someone came to you and asked for a mobile phone, so that he could talk to his girlfriend 1,000’s of miles away and chit chat about his ongoing life. You would certainly take him as a gone case and would think such thing is impossible. Well, the world evolved and interpersonal communication became more and more important. People starting looking for ways and Graham Bell came out with the first set of instruments that could convert the sound waves into electrical energy (through input transmitter), send it miles away through wires and then convert them back to sound waves (through output speakers). The impossible was done. Example 2: Slowly and gradually the world was covered with all the wires. Telephonic instruments were installed in all of the Hotels, Offices, Homes etc. People said how convenient it would be to carry a phone everytime. But with all those wires it’s impossible. Wireless technologies came in, and people found out new ways of transmission of these sound energies. Mobile phones came into pictures. Impossible was done again. Example 3: Then people said, owning a mobile and moreover talking over a mobile is too damn costly and it was impossible for almost everyone to use it for convenience purpose. Well, it’s needless to say that we all are living in an era where mobile phones are being distributed in mere INR 250 and talking over the phone has become absolutely free. Impossible is done yet again. Like these there are countless number of examples which were impossible earlier but necessities made them possible. So what do you learn out of this: Necessity makes impossible, possible. Everything is impossible for a man unless there is a necessity. Everything that you have now (which looks quite obvious to you now) was once impossible. What you feel is impossible now, will be obvious in coming years. All you need is, create a necessity and give some (sometimes a lot of) time. Considering this, yes NOTHING IS IMPOSSIBLE. How this statement is FALSE? Argument 1: Well, Nothing means, when there is no thing at all. As per Hindu Mythology, Shiva is a word given to nothingness. When Shiva is possible, that means, Nothing also must be possible. Argument 2: When you say Nothing is Impossible, you also mean that Nothing is also Not Impossible. (You might have to read and thing through this multiple times to really understand this). May sound stupid to many but is logically correct.

YES, ONLY BECAUSE OF THE MATHEMATICAL MEANING AND Wordplay. Outside of it, it is just a feel-good inspirational statement to lift ourselves. To motivate us. If you think through a little, you will realize that a lot of things are improbable. But they are definitely possible.Possibility just means that it doesn't have a probability of zero.It needs to happen once before eternity. Sure. A gazillion things will fit into this.Say, you wish to become a billionaire. It is definitely possible. Going by the precedents, human beings have done that.And of course, there is a course to be followed. You cannot not do something, and say, hey it is not possible.So there is precedence. And that itself makes it possible.But whether it is probable or not, is the problem.Improbable is the keyword here. It just means that the occurrence is so low that it really is not worth it.E.g Say you want to rob a bank. If the bank contains, 1 million dollars, and if you end up spending 2 million dollars to do the robbery, it defeats the monetary purpose of the robbery. Not worth it.So if you want to be a billionaire or a rocket scientist or a Hollywood actor, the probability becomes very low. One in 100,000 might make it. One in a million might.And I think the statement alludes more towards ‘one can become a billionaire.’ rather than ‘you can become a billionaire.’At that point, the human nature associates improbability with impossibility.But if you notice folks have become rocket scientists, Hollywood actors and billionaires.Similarly a lot of things are possible in this life, but not probable.The statement is beautiful once we don't think of it from the mathematical or wordplay aspect of it.There were probably soldiers caught in a trench, sureshot sitting ducks thinking they won't be alive tomorrow. And then they were.There are probably physically disabled people, doing therapy and recovering and ending up becoming athletes.There was probably a guy who fell into the lake, about to die, but swam his way to his boat or a shore. Thousands across the years wouldn't have made it.It also denotes that all that we see around us: millionaires, celebrities, intellectuals, sports people, world changers, or a good citizen. We can be all that we want to be.As you can see, there is a lot of wordplay in it. So a better takeaway from the statement is not its truth value, but the inspirational quotient of the statement.

No. There are plenty of things that are mathematically impossible, such as the three famous impossibilities (“square a circle”, “trisect an angle”, “duplicate a cube”). Please note that there are specifics to this before you rush off to prove me wrong. For instance, trisecting an angle must be done using only a straightedge and a compass - no ruler, no templates - nothing else. There are things that are easier to show impossible, such as the square of a real number being negative, the sum of a number and its reciprocal being sqrt(3)*, a ball hit completely horizontally from ground level flying out and going over a wall 400 feet away, finding a way to divide by zero that is consistent with the rest of mathematics**, and so, so many more. *Note that there was a question on Quora last week that actually started with that as an assumption. Most solvers never considered its impossibility and consequently gave meaningless answers. (We all make mistakes - I have made plenty and will continue to almost surely as long as I live. Key is to try to minimize the severity and the frequency.) **There was a whack job in England several years ago who claimed he found a way to divide by zero, but he was full of sh@$. Despite his Ph.D. in computer science, his knowledge of math was off and it turns out that what he suggested had been done long ago. And to the guy’s shame, he was subjecting 10-year-old kids to his nonsense, knowing they could not rebut him or even understand.

I believe it is laudable and lionizing, but ultimately will disappoint many. Just as the man who places his bet on the roulette wheel, then sees his number “hit,”believes he is in some way worthy or deserving, so will all who witness the win be confirmed in their magical thinking that is it is indeed possible for them, as well. Possible, yet unlikely. Pasteur once said that chance favors the prepared mind. Sometimes, but not always. Laying a scientific or schematic groundwork upon which to build bears no resemblance to stumbling on a once in a lifetime event. I had an uncle who was a truck driver. Many years ago, he took his wife to Las Vegas for a small vacation. Just before they left, at 3 a.m., he went in to use the restroom before the long ride back to California. Once inside the stall, he found a brown paper bag. Peering in, he could see it was filled with $100 bills. He grabbed his wife and did not stop the car until they were in their driveway hundreds of miles away. With that money, he paid off his children’s debts. Within two years, both offspring were in debt again. He drove his 18-wheeler until retirement, then bought himself a small piece of property in Northern California and lived in a trailer there until he died. He was a modest man and the money allowed him to live out his life modestly. Did he ever think it was possible he would find a quarter of a million dollars in likely drug money in a toilet in Las Vegas? Did it change his children’s lives? Did it change his? What is possible is that which you earn because of who you are rather than what you expect life will, or should, bring you. Anything else that arrives is simply a blessing to be reckoned with, but not because it is your due. Next time you go into a public restroom, look for that bag. How much are you willing to wager that it will be there if nothing is impossible? The question is if it is probable.

We don’t know for sure. It could be true. But if we make one very simple, but utterly consequential assumption… the answer must definitely be that yes, anything is possible, and further, that everything is actually not only possible, but in fact inevitable. That one assumption is that time is infinite in both ‘directions’, forward and backward. The simplicity of this concept is belied by its immensity and unfathomability for a normal human brain like mine, and most of ours. We just cannot quantify the necessarily uncountable ‘measure’ of infinity. But our feeble minds can’t help but try. Quantifying everything is our primary method for trying to understand everything that we can observe. It’s our best method for trying, in the day to day, anyway. -I digress. Back to it, then… Assuming time is infinite- ‘forward’ Everything that can happen, will happen. And, since there is no end to the time domain, a literally unlimited number of things (everything) will come to pass. Assuming time is infinite- ‘backward’ Everything that can happen has also already happened. Further, …and this is where even approaching the idea becomes very fuzzy for my fragile brain… Everything possible, (see again; everything!) may (must?) also be happening all at the same time. Right ‘now’. -For lack of a better, more accurate concept. That last part is where I am think we begin to approach as yet undiscovered and indescribable ‘dimensions’ or something of the like. I cannot even begin to make sense of things past our physical three, and sort of, time as a fourth dimension. To sum everything up: If time is infinite, then everything that is possible will occur, has already occurred, and will occur again an infinite number of times endlessly. And possibly, everything is constantly and concurrently, happening in some dimension. Experts, and truly intelligent folks, please correct me if I’m certainly wrong here in some way. I find this to be potentially a fundamental truth about all existence, however, again.. I may not be understanding something or many things that are critical. Anyone else, please share any thoughts you have. I’d love to hear them and examine them, as they relate to this idea. Edit: In the immediacy of our commonly perceived ‘real’, single lifetimes.. there are many things that are probably or even definitely not possible, as some other answers have mentioned. In the above answer, I don’t mean to suggest that I think everything is possible for us to experience, or to happen while we are alive.

Nothingness is a word automatically reflecting its implicit opposite, ‘everythingness’, as is the reverse situation. Likewise, impossible is a word that exists in opposition to its partner in crime: possible. Such are the dualities and polar opposites inherent in these our puny concepts. Words are abstractions, and wonderfully if not beautifully vague, made of light and shadow, but just exactly where you are, in shadow or light, or some mix of the grey is debatable in every moment in every incidence. Enter maths to calm our little brains: count it that will prove it exists, or not, or could exist, or not. Nothingness is absence. As is impossible. Their opposites are presence. (Random wild assertion: I wonder if the concept of nothingness has its genesis in the fear of death : the personal and perhaps only true ‘nothingness’, or not!) Absence of what? Material absence? Nothingness of what in particular: we can answer these specific questions by observation: I have ‘nothing’ to eat etc, likewise with specific examples of possibility and impossibility : it is impossible (currently with tech how it is to the best of my knowledge) for me to lay on a cloud and count how many incidences of nothingness float by and give me a gingerbread biscuit for my travails because I can’t quite conceive how much nothingness is actually everythingness in disguise. Alas our little brains do fry so easily. These words all stand in for what is, and only describe what we perceive or know of what actually is, frankly not a lot : we do not have enough information to actually know if true and literal ‘nothingness’ actually exists anywhere, in a pocket down the loo, through a hole in a spacewall we can’t see or even as a potential Universal and by definition if it exists, it really doesn’t because it is nothing. But calling nothing Nothing doesn’t that by default make it something? See the problems? So far evidence suggests nothingness does not exist, there are the quantum fluctuations that are embedded in spacetime, however that does not make nothingness an actual impossibility- eradicate spacetime what is left? I digress, more just perhaps so far ‘nothingness’ has always thus far been something and everything but one day (which won’t actually exist as a ‘day’) we will be erased and so a true state of nothingness will come into being as a something so profoundly real from a sapien perspective, if we could be there to see our own ceasing, and the word and the concept will disappear into our own personal and species void. Perhaps ‘one day’ a total and complete Nothingness will pick up Impossible, put it in its non-mouth, give it a good non-chew then non-spit it out, and non-wander off to a different world where the observers don’t feel the need to think in black and white, and can give Nothingness a big hug and say ‘there there we believe in you, it’s all going to be alright .. have you met impossible far more fun than possible to play with!’ After all the pesky law of conservation of energy rather suggests that nothing as something and impossible as possible are going to around for quite some time having a mad tea party- just depends what hats they choose to wear on any given ‘day’.

Yes, but with some important caveats. Let's assume that maximum possibilities exist within reality, perhaps within a multiverse, for example. Now, within infinite possible realities we are limited to one per lifetime at present. Within this lifetime, there are many possible yet highly unlikely things that still may occur. In fact, any occurrence which can be proven possible is actually destined to occur eventually. Through being possible an event becomes inevitable. It may be so rare that it's occurrence is statistically insignificant but it will happen, because it can happen. Being possible implies a chance of occurrence, and if existence continues long enough, even the least likely events will eventually take place. Probability tells us that amongst a set of possible events which are most and least likely to occur. No event represented within the probability model is impossible. This is crucial for understanding the nature of both probability and reality itself. If one looks into the true limits or boundaries of possibilities included within probable events, even those so remote they may only happen once a millennium, very few things are technically impossible from a scientific, objective standpoint. Time could begin running in reverse, for example, without violating the known laws of physics. A single person could lose every game they play for the span of an 85 year life. It is not common. It is not average. But it is possible, and if humanity lasts long enough this will occur. Just like the person who wins at every game will be born one day, time and population permitting. So, actually, although many extreme scenarios are highly unlikely, they are technically quite possible, just exceedingly rare. I am not arguing for an individual to place one's hopes in the hands of something only .00002 percent likely to occur. Turning one's existence over to the fates so completely for any reason will probably not result in a fulfilling life. If we can look beyond the mundane, however, the idea of what is truly possible can be a source of inspiration, spark our creativity, and potentially lead to new insights and innovations that see beyond individual comforts to a bigger picture of the human race and the cosmos with potential to spark innovations and insights from the genius in us all.

I think it is about the most aspirational statement ever spoken or written. It is difficult to respond to and impossible to disprove, like Anselm’s theory of God’s existence—that which is greater than anything you can imagine. Nothing is impossible simply means that in an infinitely large universe of an infinite number of occurrences, anything can happen at any time… But on a practical level here on earth, where life is short and gravity is a strong force bearing down on us, this sort of statement seems preposterous. Can a man on social security walk onto the field and play NFL football? Can a person with no scientific training discover a cure for a cancer? Yes, possible, but improbable. And probability is a more reliable marker.

It depends how you define your question. To start with the term “nothing”, it seems impossible to define what it is. No kidding. In theology, there is the notion that God created “ex nihilo” (out of nothing), but in the last century or so, what exactly this nothing was before anything was created, has become a major question. Later, nothing was defined as a vacuum. I remember that the intuitive idea was to suck all matter out of a certain amount of space, and an experiment showed that the presence of a vacuum within two half balls has the surprising effect that the halfs can not be separated (or at least with extreme force that might break the half balls in stead of separating them). However, as time progressed (and my knowledge about vacuum was updated), it turns out that spontaneous matter creation happens in a vacuum. This was discovered by a Dutch physicist in 1948, and the effect is called after him, the Casimir effect. Two thin plates are measured to attract each other in a vacuum if they are placed close enough to each other. The explanation is that the random matter creation is likely to happen on the outside of the plates, but not between them. So, the matter that is temporarily formed causes a pressure from the outside only. Hence, vacuum is not “nothing” either. What is “nothing”? That is the million dollar question. In an intuitive reading of your question, it is half of a negative statement. “Not something” or “Not anything” is impossible? I believe it would be better to ask an affirmative statement such as: “Are all things possible?” But “things” here is also a vague concept, and the answer is likely no. Do you mean objects, or actions, or circumstances? It’s only by defining what the question means that it becomes a bit clearer if the predicate “is possible” is applicable. It may be possible to confirm that all things that can be imagined and are logically possible to exist, can actually be made. Or that any action that can be imagined and is logically possible, can actually be performed. Or that any situation or circumstance that can be imagined and is logically possible to occur, can actually occur. There is a theorem of probability theory that point in this direction: The probability that an event w with a probability p > 0 will happen tends to 1 as the number of events increases.Note. The probability p > 0 can be as small as you want. As the probability 1 – p is close to 1, but not equal to 1, (1 – p )^n will exponentially decrease with increasing n. But the probability will still be rather high if n is of the order 1/p. Especially if p is very small, (1 – p)^(1/p) ~ 1/e, and so if n = k/p, (1 – p)^n ~ (1/e)^k. To make this probability smaller than say 0.001, we have to take k at least to be about 7, hence n about 7/p for p very small. If p is about 1/1,000,000, it means that if we repeat the experiment about 7,000,000 times, that the probability that the event has occurred is now larger than 1 - 0.001 = 0.999. Still, with a probability of 0.001 it may not have occurred yet . . . As an application, we can say that for sure the Earth will be hit by a meteor, because it has been hit in the past at least once (Gulf of Mexico). So, we know there is a positive probability it will be hit. However, to alleviate the fear, the expected time before it happens again may be so far in the future, that it could be more likely that the Earth will be destroyed by the explosion of the Sun first. Why? Well, the meteor that hit the Earth in the past is definitely gone and won’t hit us again. We actually don’t know anything about this “positive probability”, as there isn’t any working model of meteorites hitting the Earth. Regardless, we can see on the surface of the Moon that it has been hit by numerous meteorites. It is hard to compare the fate of the Moon with that of the Earth. Perhaps the likelihood of a meteorite hitting the Moon is larger . . . It is a tricky situation. Another application might be that it is possible for an avalange to hit a train in the Alps with a small probability. Well, then it will certainly happen given enough time. Or, there is a small probability that a driver gets a heart attack on a freeway. Then it is certain that there will be accidents on the highway of which the cause is a heart attack. Etc. In the positive. If it is possible for mutations to improve an organism to become “smarter”, it will certainly happen given enough generations (and mutations). This is a theory that could explain why humans exist. But it doesn’t necessarily explain why we exist on Earth. (That is more subtle.)

Here's my answer to a similar question. O Nothing. No thing. Thing. No. N0. 0 0, what is zero? Does zero represent Nothing? Does nothing represent zero? Does nothing represent zero. This is not mere repetition. Absence. David’s absence, Sam’s absence, Frank’s absence. Does the totality of absences equal Nothing? Is absence a thing? We can experience someone's absence, so do we experience a bit of Nothing then? We can think our own absence from the world, but can we think nothing? God is not a thing, not any thing. Does that make God Nothing? Is that what we mean when we say God created everything, from Nothing? Has Nothing always existed? Taoism teaches that Nothing is useful, as a window is a Nothing that lets light in, as the Nothing in a cup allows it to hold tea. If Nothing is useful, must it exist for there to be something? Is Nothing the luminous void of which Buddhism speaks? Is the void a thing? You can't grasp it, yet it can be contained. You can't see it, but it is useful. You can have it in your pocket, but you can't hold onto it. So, it's not a thing in the ordinary sense. Is it a concept, that sort of thing? Once again, you can't grasp, hold, or get a handle on thinking utter absence, until you name it. Nothing. There, now it's something. We've done it., we've labeled it, put a handle on it. Now we can use it, as 0, as a starting stage for whatever mathematical or philosophical drama we wish to create. Being that can be understood, then, is language. Does that mean that Nothing is language? Of course it does. Nothing is a part of 2 binary oppositions: 1) nothing/something and 2) nothing/everything. This is the use I referred to in the example of the window and the cup.This is the abstract use. This is the use that stuns our minds when we try to think it. No. Literally, it's not true, as I can't just up and do anything I want. I can't fly or run through walls or lift city buses. But as this statement isn't usually meant literally, but is meant as a motivational tool, well...it's still not true. While I can't literally lift a bus, I suppose it's not entirely impossible, just highly unlikely, that I can play point guard for the Celtics. I'm thinking inductively here, in matters of likelihood. So, technically, it's not impossible for me to do so.  But really, practically, it's impossible. No matter how hard I try, how much I want it, how much I train, it's nearly impossible for me to be point guard for the Celtics. So effectively, it's a false statement.  We say such things to motivate us and to make us feel good. I suppose that's not bad. But feeling good about a statement doesn't make it true.

There are some definition problems. Nothingness is how we define a situation where there isn’t anything. But we can never be in a situation where there isn’t anything simply because we will always be there or be able to observe it. It’s possible for this situation to exist, but it will never be possible to observe it, or for us to be aware of it. Even in space, where there are large spatial areas with no particles, no waves, no energy signatures, we don’t call it nothingness. We call it a vacuum. At any given moment, something could pass through that area, and at that point it couldn’t be called nothingness. Even the movement of space itself is enough to deny any definition of area that would pass that test. This concept is best understood as a continuum or a metaphor.

In high school I wanted to be a star football player. Maybe play in college. Who knows maybe the NFL. I was too light for the line, too short for end, too slow for running back. And threw wobbly spirals. I wanted to be Magnum P.I. I even looked a little like Tom Selleck. Well at least I had a mustache. I’m 5′10″, no acting ability and don’t own a Ferrari. I started as a financial adviser and wanted to build a new kind of practice. Was told, “You’ll fail, it’s impossible.” 20 years later I’ve built a large practice and the naysayers are all gone. See of course there are things for each of us that are impossible. I just see people call things impossible that aren’t. Too many give up on their dreams way too easily. Because our best dreams come wrapped in packages that make them seem impossible. So take time to analyze yourself. What are your strengths and weaknesses? Think about your dreams. What are you passionate to accomplish? Then look at your opportunities. What steps can you honestly take right now? Finally, look through the lens of possibility not impossibility. Who knows what you might achieve. Hey maybe you can become Magnum PI.

What I personally feel is, anything that is Practically and Potentially possible is not impossible. Now Practically possible and Potentially possible are two different things. Practically possible is something which can be done, just can be done, it doesn't matter by whom, by a country, a team, a person or a company etc. Term Potentially possible differs from person to person and their capabilities. What is potentially possible for you to do might not be possible for me to do and vice versa. If someone says - Ajay can you bowl faster than Shoaib Akhtar's best? that is around 100.2 miles per hour (161 kmph approx), that is potentially not possible for me to do, so it is impossible in one sense but a kind of potential impossibility in my opinion. But this is a thing which is Practically possible. Had Shoaib Akhtar not broken the barrier of bowling @100mph first, people would have considered bowling @100mph too as an impossible thing. So there might be someone in the world who can bowl faster than that of Akhtar's best, it's that just we haven't seen him yet. Another important factor is "TIME". In 18th century no one would have thought that humans can reach to moon and now humans are examining every single planet of our solar system and are researching on, if Mars is a livable planet for humans or not. So something, that was impossible in an old century is now possible. Many things are there, that're practically impossible even now i.e. Can human run at a speed of 200kmph? Today it is impossible, and if we ask anyone to do so, he will say you mad why asking such stupid question. But who knows if it becomes reality after 2-4 century from now.

In 1962 Jack Kirby said he saw a women lift a car off a baby. Witnessing this gave him the idea for Hulk. In 1982 in Georgia, a man was repairing his Chevy impala when the jacks gave way and pinned him under the car. His mother lifted the car off him long enough for two neighbors to replace the jacks and get her son out from under. In 2006 in Arizona, a Chevy Camero hit 18 year old Kyle Holtrust who was then stuck under the car. Tom Boyle lifted the Camero off Kyle long enough for the driver who hit him to pull him out. At the time, Tom deadlifted triple the world record weight. These stories go on and on. When you try to research why this is, some references talk about adrenaline but actual supporting evidence is far and few. This phenomenon tends to happen only under life and death situations. In other words, when necessity demands it of you. I tend to think more about the power the mind and spirit have over the body. There’s really no other explanation. Following that thought along, what are you then capable of? What things that are clearly impossible, can you do? I’ve thought about things like this most of my life. I believe wholeheartedly that we all have much more horsepower than we ever actually give ourselves credit for. It’s the difference between extraordinary and simply ordinary. Challenge yourself to stop thinking in normal terms. Stop limiting yourself based on experience or what’s proven to be achievable, doable or realistic. Start imagining what’s potentially or theoretically possible and pursue it. Whatever your goals or visions — work to shift into that extra gear that is somewhere deep inside you. It is possible.

Surely this is a MIND-BOGGLING question which has been vexing our mind since long , yet no clear consensus is reached . I would like to see it from a different perspective as such .Enough is said about the acceptance or deniel on this qestion. I intend to examine the issue from its REALISTIC ANGLES . When we say ‘nothing is impossible, we mean it in the same sense when we say ‘They lived happily ever'. When we say they lived happily ever, we don't mean that they were IMMORTAL and they lived FOREVER ’ .Ever means at all times, always. Its synonym is ETERNAL. So too, when we say nothing is impossible, we in fact we don't mean ‘ NOTHING’ IS ANYTHING and IMPOSSIBLE is UNBOUNDED or LIMITLESS specially in the context of the reality that man himself is BOUNDED BY LIMITATIONS. For, he is no God . Therefore this is a MISNOMER. We CONTRADICT ourselves between what we say and what we imply. Because when we talk of man ,we have implicitly accepted the fact that man has limitations and his ACTIONS are bound to be limited too whatever limit that might be. SO THE REALITY ABOUT THE SITUATION HAVE REVEALED THAT MAN IS ENDOWED WITH SO MUCH OF HIS POWERFUL CAPABILITIES THAT HE CAN REACH UNIMAGINABLE HEIGHT BUT NOT THE SUPREME HEIGHT TO BE SYNONYMOUS WITH ANY LIMITLESS IMPOSSIBILITY. AND HERE THIS POSITION OF THE ISSUE IS ASSESSED IN THE CONTEXT OF MAN'S POSITION TODAY I would like to cite an example to substantiate the above line of thinking Man endowed with exceptional qualities and capabilities, have made great advancements in science & technology and in other domains. But a fact that causes great astonishment for man is that man has not been able to CREATE WITH ORIGINALITY a single product or element inspite of his magnificent BRAIN POWER. Whatever he has done is TRANSFOMATION or changing the shapes, sizes and color etc Dissecting ,MIXING,twisting, gathering of originals are activities described as PROCESSING and RESEARCH . All the inventions are on pre existed matters or elements of NATURE AND THE NATURE,S LAW operates BEHIND every invention . EVEN those products like color claimed to be original are in fact are effects obtained from pre existed originals. But my citing of the above example is intended only to analyse the reality of man’s position today and to look at the question from this real perspective However ,this is also not meant that there is no possibility that the above situation will change . Possibility is also a relative term and anything is possible .TODAY’S IMPOSSIBLITY IS TOMORROW ‘S POSSIBILITY. THE ANSWER IS, DEPENDS ON THE TIME AT WHICH YOU SET YOUR GOALS. " Nothing is impossible, the word itself says, I'm possible," says Audrey Hepburn. GOALS AT THE WRONG TIME Let's say you are 60 years old, but you wish to travel at a speed of light by inventing a new plane ( Elon Musk is trying to make one such thing). It is right now impossible for you. For it, you need to research and work for many years from the age of youth. Here your target is not at the right time, that's why you cannot achieve. AIM AT THE RIGHT TIME On the other hand, suppose, your age is between 6-40 years old.And your dream is to invent a new 'lightning speed plane.' It is possible for you at this age to do such thing. Many things that we would think could never happen, are actually possible. He recovered, but started showing an insatiable interest in music. He acquired a piano and started teaching himself to play. Despite not showing any prior interest in music, he was able to compose music and gave several recitals. Look up acquired savant syndrome.* My Professor in college who taught Probability Theory used to say that by the Law of Large numbers any event that has non-zero probability will happen at some point given that enough time has passed. So in an eternal Universe everything that can physically be possible happens! Would I live my life in the hopes I’d be struck by lightning and acquire a skill that would make me successful? Unlikely events are an unexpected surprise, but they only enhance my life, I don’t base my entire life on that chance. If something is improbable or implausible then it is impossible. Statement: Humans could go to Mars. Possible. We just don't know yet how. We did make it to the Moon, didn't we? Statement: Humans could go to Mars in an 18th-century chariot. (Sorry, that was the best I could come up with!) Impossible. There needs to be a certain baseline of knowledge and awareness that informs one about the improbability or implausibility of something to determine that it is indeed impossible. For instance, a nuclear or aeronautical scientist will tell that an inter-stellar or inter-planetary rocket can be propelled by ionic wind (the so-called electrohydrodynamic effect). This may seem "impossible" to someone in the 21st century who is, to put it more euphemistically, less aware and knowledgeable, or to someone who existed in BCE (Before Common Era). But, unlike them, the aforementioned scientists have a reasonable baseline of knowledge and awareness to hypothesize as such. Don't fool yourself by chasing something that you have determined to be implausible and improbable. You can choose to resume the chase later when you are ready or you can just let go. And who is the best person to make this determination for you? You.

Man Teaches Poor Kids MS Word By Drawing It On Blackboard. Where There’s A Will, There’s A Way. There are many countries in the world where the basic necessities of people are not fulfilled so expecting the government of that nation to provide good education to kids is futile. Recently, he took to Facebook to tell people about the method that he is using to teach his children the subject of ICT (Information and Communications Technology) and that too without a computer.  He draws a computer on the blackboard and makes students feel that he is actually looking at the computer screen.  This method has worked well with the kids and they are enjoying his classes. I think it’s very motivational. When the railroads were being built, medical authorities assured us that the human body couldn’t handle speeds over thirty miles an hour. Lister’s germ theory was ridiculed. So was Madame Curie. Newton thought the universe was infinite and eternal, and that the atom was the smallest natural building block, then relativity and quantum mechanics came along. There were those who assured us the Higgs Boson was a myth, and that Cern was just wasting money. We were assured we could never get past the Asteroid Belt to reach Mars, then we landed two probes, there. Thirty years ago, “cancer” was still an automatic death sentence. The list of “impossible things” assured us by the “best minds” could fill a house. The fact is, we have no idea what is possible or impossible. For a fallen people living on a fallen planet, we have managed to harness our brain-power to do enormous good, and our courage to take the necessary risks to make great explorations. All because we’ve held, “Nothing is impossible” as axiomatic.

It is meaningful only in the context of faith—Luke 1:37. the angel Gabriel to the Blessed Virgin: 37 For with God nothing shall be impossible. The universe runs on the laws of physics. Things fall under gravity, not rise. Mass-energy is conserved. Only a few atoms can undergo fission. Further, each of us as individuals have talents and limitations. I have no athletic talents, and could no more run a 4 minute mile than I could breathe underwater without equipment. I see in a few other responses some very whifty New Age attitude—I cannot in justice call it thought. We are not in an “illusory matrix”; “quantum reality” underlies what we see day by day, and is part of the laws of physics. There are many impossible things in this universe, and there are things which are impossible for each of us as individuals. The goal is to recognized what you cannot do, and, most importantly, what you can do.

Absolutely nothing is impossible. One of my teacher Renu Khublani told us about a recent study at IIT, Dr. Ray Menon placed rats in a pool of water to test how long they could tread(walk in) water. On average they'd give up and sink after 15 minutes. But right before they gave up due to exhaustion, the researchers would pluck them out, dry them off, let them rest for a few minutes - and put them back in for a second round. In this second try - how long do you think they lasted? Remember - they had just swam until failure only a few short minutes ago... How long do you think? Another 15 minutes? 10 minutes? 5 minutes? No! 60 hours! That's not an error. That's right! 60 hours of swimming. The conclusion drawn was that since the rats BELIEVED that they would eventually be rescued, they could push their bodies way past what they previously thought possible. This study give a thought of : *If hope can cause exhausted rats to swim for that long, what could a belief in yourself and your abilities, do for you?* Believe can make us do anything impossible, just like rats in this study , 60 hours of swimming means 2 and half day and that too for rats it was something above impossible but they did it because they believed in themselves . Keep working hard and believing till your last breath. NOTHING IS IMPOSSIBLE.

It might be true, if we could examine an argument for the proposition that, “Nothing is impossible.” Thus far, no arguments in support of that declarative have been identified. Examination would have to be offered regarding the definition of the basic terms, “nothing” and “impossible” and “things”. Some distinction might need to be made between several declaratives, such as: “Nothing is impossible.” “All things are possible.” “Nothing is possible.” However, little can be known until an argument is identified. Other declaratives might be considered, such as. “Possibilities exist.” “Possibilities do not exist.”  In the end, the designation, “exists” or “exist” must be defined. So long as no arguments are identified, there is no need to consider the question about possibility or impossibility.

No. If nothing is impossible, then everything is possible. If everything is possible, then it is possible for something to be impossible.
